posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>NTSC release says that Metroid Prime is a Metroid-like creature they found in the Impact Crater which was extremely adaptive to their phazon experiments. Prime assimilated Space Pirate weapons and escaped back to the Crater.
>Ok, but how the fuck did the Space Pirates find it originally if they were locked out of the Impact Crater by the Chozo Temple which was built to contain "The Worm" AKA Metroid Prime?
>Metroid Prime is hinted at, by Pirate lore, to be a Metroid which escaped captivity and became mutated from the phazon in the Crater. Then what the fuck is "The worm which uses Great Poison to rot the planet from within" and came from a meteor, according to Chozo lore??
>If Metroid Prime was meant to arrive on Talon IV in the phazon meteor as the Worm from prophecy, why does everything else in the game suggest it was purely a Space Pirate experiment gone wrong?

>PAL release retcons all this, says Metroid Prime was sealed away the entire time the Space Pirates were on Talon IV.
>Metroid Prime still has space pirate weaponry even though its never had the chance to assimilate them, being trapped in the Impact Crater for thousands of years and all.
>Impact Crater still has Fission Metroids despite the fact that Metroids are not native to Talon IV and were brought by Space Pirates. So how did they get in there?

https://metroid.fandom.com/wiki/Metroid_Prime_(creature)#Inconsistencies

posts.com:
>The Chozo called upon all of their knowledge and technology to
control the power of the Phazon, but their efforts were doomed to fail. All
they could do was build a temple over the crater at the impact site, sepa-
rate the Phazon core, and seal it away. Believing that someday a savior
would return to the planet, the Chozo left for an unknown destination,
leaving behind nothing but engraved accounts of their time on Tallon IV

Despite all this, Chozo logs frequently mention Space Pirates and what they've done to Tallon IV. Who wrote these, if half the Chozo had ascended/fled elsewhere and the other half were schizophrenic ghosts who wandered the temples and attacked everything on sight? How did they write logs on things that hadn't happened yet? And if they're somehow watching Samus and influencing the writing she scans on walls, why don't they ever speak to her or celebrate the coming of The Child?

>>9653532

Adults generally don't ask why the crabs sing either, because Disney is better at making cartoon musicals than comic book nerds are at making gritty superhero stories, and they find ways to fit everything together pretty well. Adults ask why stupid stuff that clashes with other parts of the story and thus shouldn't have been in the story is in fact in the story. It is possible for a Batman story to simply be crappy.

In Metroid Prime, the text logs are garbage, regardless of whether they contain easily repaired plot holes. They're boring and they block play. The solution to that problem AND to the problems OP points out is simple and obvious: Remove them all. But nerds must clot everything up with walls of words and with gritty science fiction that tells us about sad noble mystics fighting against greedy warmongering materialists for the billionth time, so Metroid Prime was shipped with its biggest flaw intact.

Same with any art form. To make something good you need to develop your taste, and you do that by looking at what other people do and thinking about what you like or don't like about it.

You do things that you think are cool, you don't do things that you think suck, but you have to know what you think is cool or what you think sucks first. You have no idea what other people like even when they tell you, but you can know exactly what you like.

I have finished ALT and it feels like I had a religious experience and not in a good sense of that word. A dozen of good maps tops, everything else was unbearable. In some levels you just don't know if you are looking at the wall, a door, a usable switch or a shootable switch. Other maps have platforming, tightrope walking in the seizure rooms, self-telefragging mazes, switches which seemingly do nothing but open some nook on the other side of a giant map, switches which can softlock some maps if you pressed them in the wrong time (map 13, fuck you).
The last level was genuinely disappointing. Map 28 had you scaling the giant flesh tumor thing while avoiding cyberdemons' rockets so you can telefrag its eye (?) and in map 29 you scale the imploded remains of the same tumor so you can jump inside of it to go into the shadow zone of the crashed plane on the second level with ghost soldiers. Now, map 30 has you walking through the flesh texture plains avoiding revenants and chaingunners, going into the maze full of lost souls and pain elementals where the automap doesn't do shit, so you can get into the arena and just non stop fire a BFG under invulnerabilty into the fenced monsters. waiting for teleporter to appear.
I love it and hate this wad so much. 8/10! Don't play this thing!

Remember to always wait for others and have fun!

posts.com:
I just finished F.E.A.R. It was alright.
Lots of people have said the AI is amazing, but I don't think so. Most of the callouts they would shout would be just plain wrong. The way they split into cover and tried to get behind the player was nothing groundbreaking either. No more complex than what elites did in Halo.
The shotgun was certainly fun to use, but little of that was in the gun itself - all the feedback is in how the enemies gib. Which is excellent to see in slow motion.
The rest of the roster of guns was plain, so I found myself using the shotgun most of the time, with the particle rife for tougher enemies.
Speaking of those - there wasn't nearly enough variety. Occasionally you'd get one of those heavily armored troopers. Or a bunch of drones together. But I think the combat would have been better served by mixing between things more often. Instead, it was just room after room of guys who are ready to be gibbed by the shotgun, posing no threat.

How do the sequels shape up compared to it?

>>9653279
The expansions have a pretty common bug where roughly halfway through Extraction Point the game will start crashing during loading the next level. But the new weapons are very satisfying to use at least.

I got around the issue by setting all graphics settings to the lowest and putting them back to full after successfully loading into the next level.

>>9653108
The lack in enemy / sequence variety is my biggest gripe, followed by the extremely slow jogging speed of the main character. One of the reasons why I love Half Life 1 so much is because it switched up it's setpieces and gameplay dynamics around a lot. One moment you're jumping over moving industrial machinery, then you're fighting grunts in literal trenches and machine gun positions, powering up railroad tracks so you can drive a cargo locomotive through the transportation system.

The base game FEAR also does a decent job of pacing the experience with NPC dialogue and meeting up with your team so even if the gameplay remains samey, there are some things to direct your interest other than just the shooting. Some parts of the expansions are better than others, like the parts of XP where you team up with a Delta Force guy are better than the sections where you go through long stretches alone without even the comlink guy talking to you. But each to their own.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9653108
FEAR definitely has issues. Most notably the repetitiveness... you can play the first few levels and that's about all the game's got to offer for a maximum of 7 or so hours.
You're fighting in impossible office spaces and sewers, and that's about it. They're very blocky (fine, accomodates the AI) and not very interesting to look at.
The Shotgun is about the only gun you need. Having a powerful shotgun is great, but many games get the Doom 2 syndrome, where the main powerhorse is so powerful and versatile, that there is very little incentive to use other weapons.
Doom pwads (not much Doom 2 itself lol) such as Plutonia will require the player to switch up weapons to fit drastically different scenarios, to avoid this issue and generate variety. FEAR never really does that. The other 2 weapon choices only exist in case you run out of shotgun ammo.
Not a game I care to replay, but a good experience and one of the best of the generic FPS at the time.
Also, Halo Elites really were peak AI. One of the most fun enemies to fight in vidya, period. I'm surprised people love to mention FEAR's but never Halo's, which was even more impressive, and made years earlier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653108
FEAR's AI was not all that special under the hood, but Monolith designed the whole game around its strengths and made enemies more agressive than your average shooter at the time had. Together with some neat features like it being able to hop through windows, and great sound design (combat communications of the clones and their lines changing to nervous and panicking when they lose more than half of the squad), it made them stand out. In one of the expansions, i think it was Perseus Mandate, third party devs tried to make fights in open areas with AI companion, and it looked awful: just bots standing and shooting other bots because they didn't have paths to go anymore.
>I found myself using the shotgun most of the time, with the particle rife for tougher enemies.
Same here, except i held to dual pistols for as long as i could find ammo for them and heavies weren't so common. Great for headshots.
>How do the sequels shape up compared to it?
Everyone is saying 2 is better than 3 but i just can't play it after the first game. Guns have no feedback, enemies are lit like a Christmas tree with some stupid looking neon appliances, they go in waves like in CoD, control scheme is weird with limited remapping options and with goddamn mouse acceleration (leftovers from it being a console first title, thank God there is a fix for mouse on PC)... Oh, and there are lots of text messages that you need to read from menu instead of audio logs, and it is not like they are all that interesting to read. I just don't know, i didn't play it more than a couple of hours because of how bland it seems.
I didn't even touch 3, but seen some videos on it lately, and it honestly seems more interesting than 2, especially with the option to play as Paxton, hopping between posessed enemies. The coop mode when you needed to outrun the wall of darkness seemed interesting too, but i guess it is long dead.

>>9650637
If you haven't installed Q-Zandronum for SNS already, you should do that now. Being a distinct fork of Zandronum, you'll also have to rebind your keys.

The server will broadcasted to the master.qzandronum.com:15300 master server, so your doomseeker should be configured to fetch servers from there. The doomseeker that came installed with Q-Zandronum should be pre-configured for this, so you can just use that. I noticed that having the server set to favorites will erroneously display it as a Zandronum 3.1 server instead of a Q-Zandronum one. If you get this error, just remove the server from your favorites, close doomseeker, wait a minute, then re-open doomseeker. That should be everything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9651834
California is a crooked fucking place, this kind of shit isn't very rare. District Attorneys and prosecutors are also notoriously predatory as is.

Rojas doesn't even really have an audience either, is the thing. He was mostly active modding Wolf and Doom in the 1990s and early 2000s, and he left his mark with that stuff, but it was never the highest profile. He moved on to other things, also, trying to pursue acting and writing, where he didn't have very good luck.
For the majority of these fandom's time, he's mainly remembered by older users one of the early pioneers who moved on, he's not one of those guys who stuck around all this time and remained a prolific contributor, or one of those who came around to check things for a while every few years.

The most exposure he's had in a long while was all the way back in 2016 where he had an interview with Vice which paints him as struggling and unsuccessful, not touching much on his videogame stuff, telling of recent misfortune, which then snowballs the fuck out of control.
It feels rude to say, but he's a has-been in these communities, and he's not famous for anything else, faint threads to old times is essentially the one ship he could signal to when lost out at sea with no other rescue, so to say.

Not gonna lie, there's a niggling worry in the back of my mind that this could be a con, either just Laz himself, or possibly he died in prison while awaiting his trial, and someone is assuming his identity, maybe exploiting an otherwise true story. He's had his identity stolen before, got basically robbed back in 2017, and with rotten luck like his, I can see it happening to him even after death, the guy's been rolling snake eyes for a decade.

I only tossed him some pocket change, so I don't have much at stake, but so far, it's all believable.
As I said about Cali, the place is rotten and the criminal justice system is a massive farce, so far I'm not sensing any rank odour of bullshit from this story.

>>9657759
Gonna second the other guy.

A full one-man megawad can be quite daunting though, a lot of people set out to do that early in their mapping career, but then find that they don't have the steam to go through with it. If you find yourself losing your drive halfway through, or like the levels feel like obligations, then consider if you can just plain wrap it up. Consider also that there are many levelsets which aren't even 10 maps long yet are classics still getting enthusiastic recommendations, and that with UMAPINFO, so much of the game's structure is on your terms, a set of maps which end at 10 don't need to unceremoniously spit the player out into O' Of Destruction.

Not saying don't, there's some good one-man megawads out there, it can be worth it, just that you shouldn't feel like you have to force yourself.

>if you rewind before you got hit.. did you really learn how to dodge that attack?
Yes, because if you don't learn how to dodge it then you'll just get hit again and become stuck in a rewind loop until you learn how to not get hit. It's actually a much faster way to learn.

Without rewind, you either take the hit without dying and keep moving forward having learned little-to-nothing until next time or you die and restart the entire stage and have to replay until you get to the part where you died and try not to die.

With rewind, you get hit and then immediately rewind so you can analyze what hit you and why, then keep rewinding until you know exactly how to avoid it. It's the same practice loop as above, just done immediately instead of spread out over a long period of time.

The post I originally replied to literally says:
>i eventually learn to beat it because i'm picking up on stuff and applying learned muscle memory to this difficult situation.
Which is all much more quickly learned through immediate repetition. It's the difference between improving your free throw in basketball by throwing 100 free throws each day and improving your free throw by playing an entire game of basketball each day. One gives you distinctly fewer repetitions of what you're trying to improve. You need to practice the whole game, too, obviously, but these individual fundamental skills are best improved through maximum repetition. If you want to master dodging a specific boss's attack then the best thing you can do is rewind repeatedly until you've got all the cues and timings down. Practicing the game as a whole is a separate thing with a different practice method.

>>9640856
Is it mental gymnastics to say that throwing 100 free-throws in a row is better free-throw practice than playing an entire game of basketball? The latter will take significantly more time but offer significantly fewer chances for a free-throw. If you want to practice beating one specific section of a game, it's better and faster practice to repeat that section over and over than to restart the entire game each time.

To use a more video game oriented analogy, competitive fighting game players go into practice mode and repeatedly practice inputs for the same move or combo repeatedly for long stretches of time. That way when the pressure is on during a real game they're less likely to drop their inputs. Playing a whole match is also practice, but if you want to practice one move the best thing to do is just repeat it over and over, same goes for rewinding a single segment repeatedly until you have it down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In my opinion save states are only acceptable in the following circumstances:

- For NES era games that lack a saving function or credit system. Using a save state at the beginning of a world / set of levels instead of starting over from the very beginning.
- To suspend your game and pick up where you left off (like leaving your console on overnight)
- As a replacement for passwords as they can be a hassle to put in

Otherwise it's unacceptable. Rewinds are always unacceptable for obvious reasons, as there also isn't a cognitive learning process if you instantly rewind. Your brain won't learn the patterns like that, despite what some people claim here.

Fastforwarding in JRPG's is understandable, especially for the NES era. But I avoid them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653032
>Did it not occur to you while writing that training modes akshually make you worse
Not sure what you're referring to. All I know is that when you instantly rewind, there won't be a cognitive learning process as your brain needs to learn (adapt to) a certain pattern with expectations and outcomes. Rewinding just brings you back to the moment right before dying, but not the moments leading up to it. Yet you'll still receive the dopamine reward in both cases, taking away the motivation to become better at the game. Rewinding also drastically reduces the possibility of failure, and failure is when your brain actually learns in order to adapt and overcome. Hence the absence of learning.

8 and 16 bit games especially have been designed with this learning process in mind. It's the literal structure of those video games. When using save states or rewinds, you bypass this learning process and don't experience the game in full how it was intentionally designed by the brightest minds of the gaming industry. What you're left with is a powerpoint slide of dopamine shots that only serve as escapism. The element of 'play' almost completely disappears. Imagine soccer but every time a player misses he can rewind and slightly adjust his foot to make sure he'll get the right angle this time. What is left of the game then? Nothing.

In short, rewinding makes you a worse gamer in the long term. This is simple cognitive neurology, any scientist would agree. Save states and rewinds therefore make for an objectively inferior experience as you only experience a small aspect of the game. It's only slightly different than being a passive observer by watching a longplay on Youtube. It just baffled me how some people don't see this. I said my peace.

If you're talking about the PS2 that's the I/O problem I was referring to. The PS2 uses the PS1 CPU for PS2-related I/O so if you're going to load a game from the PS2 side then you can't run a PS1 game since the laser, controller input, memory card, etc. are all being routed via the PS1 CPU.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9659884
That's a tough one. I really like the Sonic Adventure ones. It's a basic concept of having new aesthetics in the game world for events, but it adds a lot of excitement to its world. Another one that's pretty crazy are the Shenmue VMU "Passport Goodies." Each file was a unique sprite animation to play on your VMU. They made one for every single character model in the game (not just the human NPCs but all of the differeny birds and cats and such too). In total, there were 339 of these VMU animation files for the game, although 132 of them still remain lost, sadly. It wasn't easy to get these back in the day. Not counting the default 4 that came with Shenmue's VMU animation player, you had to receive a winning can from a market in-game and then connect to the online servers of the Passport disc to exchange one winning can for one animation of your choice. I'm surprised we have over 200 of these archived to be honest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653101
I think the only way I can see your position is if you're considering "finish" to be distinct from "clear" or "beat". If that's not what it is then I don't understand your issue.
Many (not all) video games possess an end state. Score attack games have an end state; it's when the player has erred enough times. Competitive games have an end state; when one player wins or neither player is no longer eligible to win. Games focused on following a narrative have an end state; it's the conclusion of the story.
Generally games following a narrative place their credits after the conclusion of the story. This is a convention to notify the player they have finished the story and most likely the game itself. Exceptions exist but are not the common expectation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653436
I understand what you're trying to say. So in this case finishing a game is just getting to the end. Whereas I'd argue that 'finishing what you start' doesn't really imply getting through the middle. Because you can on several degrees of passivity 'finish' what you start. I merely asked why one would finish what they start, on the notion that the whole thing is tedium. This requires someone not merely to do something they consider tedium, it requires them to go against ones own logic of dropping something that is tedium that has no intrinsic value that might be used to argue for finishing something that happens to be tedious (such as filling out your taxes). I don't think, given the mindset, one can truly finish a game they consider tedium. For their mind will actively reject it after the fact.

>>9660259
Basically just get a lot of money and stock up on full restores. The first two bosses may seem annoying but if you lock down their patterns they're not too hard to get through with minimal healing. Just do whats safe (for the first guy block his projectiles then go in for an attack then run away to avoid his charge, the the second guy basically just run around the room and jump over his laser without doing much fancy stuff. He gets tired after he fires it so it's easy to hurt him.) Then basically you'll have a ton of healing items to scum for the rest of the dungeon but at the same time the game goes full on top down shooter depending on what you absorb and there's a lot of health and MP drops. The last few bosses including the final boss are actually extremely simple and not that hard so basically just getting over initial hurtle before the end is mainly what you have to worry about.

>>9659545
It means promo art blastoise would probably look weird doing any physical attacks, because the original design is so bulky and has such stubby arms that it'd be rather difficult to make anything work and look good. You can see if you watch this video. They made the arms longer so that punch animations or other hand motions would look more normal, and even then that they pretty much rely on attacks and movements that don't involve hands at all.
The classic promo art and renders are nice, and there's nothing wrong with them, but they are static images. The pokken people had to make the model as it was to get blastoise to work well in actual motion.

Also, that screenshot is, to me, a bad representation. If you watch some footage, then I think you'll see that blastoise looks perfectly fine in that game.

posts.name: Anonymous

Not sure if you're grasping all the purposes concept art can encompass. Yes it can be a literal translation, but more than often it is just inspiration at best for when the time comes to actually produce a product. There is a stark contrast between his art and the game. But if you actually look, you can put the pieces together and realize what is represented in the work. Hence, the concept art is doing its job.
How many pieces of concept art for cars have you seen that actually near completely represent the official model that gets released? It's all about interpretation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9657904
I've been playing it for the first time, albeit with a lot of familiarity from seeing my friends play a long time ago, and it's the most fun game I've emulated in a while. The "survival horror" tension is incredibly effective. Every time I enter a new room my ass is clenched listening for zombies because I don't want to get bit or waste bullets. You don't know what's going to come next, especially when there are enemies like giant spiders that you wouldn't necessarily expect to be in a zombie game. And on top of that the game is extremely well designed so that you can anticipate what comes next based on the items you found in the area you're currently in, due to familiarity with games in general, but you still don't know exactly. So it creates a very satisfying give and take where you feel like you're using your brain to survive while at the same time reacting in the moment to the unexpected.
It's also interesting to think about how this was the game that started the franchise. I know all about Umbrella and the t-virus and the characters etc. but if you played this game when it came out that would've been completely new, off the cuff, no big plan to create a franchise that would spawn a million more games. You would have no idea that there was a laboratory hidden under an elevator disguised as an ornate fountain, it would've been mind blowing. Fucking sharks in the water.
The cutscenes look great too. And it has replay value, enough that you could play it at least 4 times, then more if you want to do challenges which give cool unlocks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: At first it seemed better than the Sega arcade port, I really liked the level on the raft, the real sensations of adventure, alternative gameplay. Cool level with columns. The levels are 2 times longer, so the walkthrough longer, the checkpoint is only in the middle. The last stages are made according to the residual principle and copy the last GnG, you just climb a few stairs and at the end the boss of the first game. The bosses are made in a balanced way, there is no checkpoint in front of them, so they are easier, except for the last ones on the second run. There is a level in the gut of a ghoul, like in Earthworm Jim, quite original, you are twisted around the level, like in Super Castlevania 4, then you ride on a platform through gases, the most boring thing is that they do not show how you get there and how you get out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The weapons were spoiled here, there is no strike in 4 directions, this is the same degradation as after SuperCastlevania 4 and Bloodlines. It’s mostly bad weapon here, thr boomerang, the Death scythe from a castlvania, the torch, the axe with a strange spiral trajectory, there was so better in the prequel. In fact, only the starting spear, the classic knife, the imba crossbow and the saintball for the second run are usable. Saintball is also a terrible shit, although it is strong, you can only throw one, on the half of the screen, the farther, the weaker. In GnG it was much nicer, like magic from the end of the gothic. With it, it is almost impossible to pass the boss Satan from the first and second games. It's hard to even get to them, the red devils start to cause problems like in the first game.. The game just broke me, I made a savestate before the bosses. Even with it, I spent dozens of attempts, he needs 30 strokes, I'm fucked up. All bosses are easily taken out with a crossbow, especially magical ones, you just smear Satan on the first try, you spam with arrows without stopping. The game is broken if you are forced to walk half the game with the worst, but quest weapon.
The mainboss is similar to Loki from the prequel, but a little more complicated, you need to understand how to jump on one platform, after a few trays you can kill him. He even upset me after this Satan, I freaked out, skiped with a savestate, but immediately replayed it so that there was a sense of completeness.
In general, its good game, beautiful graphics, original levels, but the weapons of the second run and real meinbosses are very annoying. 8/10

>>9653016
It's not hard to make a Mame machine. But it's time consuming and the experience isn't the same as it was back in the 90s.

Arcade cabs usually had 1 game (unless it was a Neo Geo). And it played instantly when you dropped a quarter it in. No wait times or scrolling through tons of menus.

With Mame, people put thousands of games on their MAME machines. You walk up to a Mame machine and you can spend 10 minutes just scrolling through menus. Annoying and It really kills the vibe.

Plus you need to download roms, setup mame, fiddle with settings (which can take hours or days), test everything, tweak the controls to your likeing, and install a front-end (the pretty menu that you scroll through when choosing a game).

And worst of all, everytime Mame updates you need to re-download all your Roms again because the roms aren't compatible with the new version. I don't know why they haven't figured out a better way. If there's an error, then you deal with a lot Mame elitists who insult you and claim your an idiot. Even though Mame looks like it's still stuck in the era Windows 98. They havent updated their UI in decades.

When I want to play an arcade game, I don't want to use a computer. I want to instantly jump in the action. I don't want to deal with menus, error messages, or any other stuff that crops up.

I don't hate Mame and applaud the Mame team for preserving games. But I prefer original hardware when possible. It just feels better and less headache with setup.

Plus there are so many companies making hundreds of thousands if not millions by selling expensive custom arcade cabinets. Usually anywhere form $10K to 25K in price.

>>9653426
I've spoken with many old school arcade operators. I can offer some of their thoughts.

Some arcade machines kept track of how much they earned in the hidden operator test settings. Data would display on how much money/quarters that players put inside the machine on each difficulty. You could track the data.

If you made the difficulty too high, then casual players would give up and stop playing because it was too hard.

If you made it too easy, then the game wouldn't be seen as a challenge and your casual players would easily beat the on less quarters. Which means you earn less money.

The idea was to find the perfect middle ground. You could adjust default CPU difficulty on a scale from level 1 to level 10 in many games.

If your arcade was in an area with mostly casual players and children, then you kept the difficulty on moderate. You go easy on the kids to lure more quarters out of them. Give them just enough hope and they will give you more quarters.

For an arcade that had a lot of "pro players", operators kept the difficulty on high because they would be more of a challenge to pro players.

For some games like Fighting games, you could even adjust the default damage level.

For example, in the Philippines the the damage level was actually kept on 50% instead of the normal 100%. Kids didn't have a lot of money, so arcade owners would lower the damage so the players that visited often would be able to "feel" like they got their money's worth. Matches would be extra long due to lower damage. But this kept visitors coming to arcades. This happened in many countries in Asia, South America, and the Pacific Islands where kids had less money.

In America and Europe the damage was set to 100%

This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653543
>This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

Part 2 - Continued

There was some arguments and debates on what should be the default damage level for worldwide Marvel VS Capcom tournaments.

As an Asian/Filipino/South American player, if you spent hundreds of hours (or even a few thousand hours) learning to play your team on a lower damage setting then your whole play style revolves around that damage levels. You know how EXACTLY much damage your character can take but still survive. Or How to recover, counter, etc. It will be very difficult to adjust to higher damage.

For players in America and Europe, you've trained your muscle memory to be able to execute the combos you need to exactly kill the enemy team with damage level set to 100%. If the damage level is set to 50%, then suddenly your combos that would kill the enemy team will still leave them alive.

So there were debates and arguments between players about it. I think the American Players and European players won out because... Well they are richer and put more money into hosting the tournaments. So they decided the rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9658824
>>9658752
>I know this question is contentious and has no real answer, but how do you feel about the notion of completing a 1cc of an arcade game in a real arcade with the knowledge that said machine may actually be running on easy mode? Do you think it still counts?

First of all it must be real hardware. Emulation does not (and will never) count.

There is a reason that official record holder websites like Twin Galaxies and other websites exist. And the rule is that it must be on original hardware. It's to hold everyone to same rules and same standards.

Games like Donkey Kong require a 4 way joystick (original manufacturer design). And Using other joysticks with more available directions actually give an unfair advantage in game. There are active lawsuits right now in the real world about records being false because of using the wrong joystick.

PC computers are not universal. Everyone has different setups. Emulation can be used to cheat and there have been numerous cases of people cheating. Like with DDR and Guitar Hero record holders who've been caught faking their records. They record themselves with the gameplay speed reduced to around 90% or 80% (because they can't do it at 100% speed), then use a video editing program to speed it back up to 100%.

Or people trying to claim "Shoot Em up" or 'Run and Gun' game records, but use autofire. For example games like Metal Slug (even though it was never available in the arcades).

There are two rules when it comes to claiming records and achievements.

1. It must be on the same unmodified arcade hardware. Emulation is not accepted.

2. It must be on the same settings.

>easy mode
Are you trying to beat the game on easy mode? Then OK.

But if you want a higher difficulty, then politely talk to arcade technician/manager/owner to check the machine and change the settings. People politely ask all the time. It's not a huge deal. They might might even support what you are doing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Despite being a commercial failure this game did a lot of things right and at the time showed a lot of innovation. The core combat involves using elemental magic to defeat your enemies but what makes this interesting is that you have 4 separate mana bars for each element (earth, air, fire, water) instead of one and you can combine them all for different results. For example earth and fire make lava and air and water make ice. An interesting piece of trivia according to Stephen Clarke-Willson is that this game is the sole reason why the four primary buttons on the xbox controller are red, blue, green, and air as each button represents an element in the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9659920
You should definitely try it, it runs well enough if you emulate it using Xemu. It's an action/adventure and while the action was definitely a little undercooked the adventure seriously makes up for it. The world is split up into six elemental realms: earth, air, fire, water, life, and death. But what the game doesn't explicitly tell you is the nature of this world and the roles the realms play. At first glance it looks like a generic fantasy game but as you progress more through the game it becomes clear that it's actually a sci-fi more than fantasy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9659934
As you progress through the game you slowly start to realise that the entire world is man-made. The air realm is just a collection of aircrafts and machines that purify the air, collect water in reservoirs to artificially release as rain as well as a giant atmospheric projector as the sky. The fire realm is made of machinery to create energy through geothermal heat and there was a cut level of a steam powered dam. The earth realm is made of giant excavators and machinery to constantly toil the earth to maintain acidity and fertility. This game does a really good job of subverting the players expectations. The best example of this is when you read the manual it gives a small description of every realm from the perspective of Eldwynn who wrote it. The life realm is described as a place of pure light that no man has seen. This description would lead you to compare this to something like heaven or otherwise paradise right? Well the life realm is actually and artificial sun that is orbiting Perathia because the real sun is obstructed by a gas giant planet, meaning Perathia is actually a moon orbiting this planet. The list really goes on and on and it's honestly one of the only games I can think of that has successfully merged sci-fi and fantasy together this beautifully.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The game took some popular game tropes at the time and implemented them in an immersive way which was somewhat rare back in 2001. An example of this is double jumping as most games especially platformers had double jumping in them. Double jumping is achieved through the air power and increases every time you upgrade your power, at level 3 you can jump 6 times before touching the ground which allows you to basically fly for a short amount of time. This game has a sort of metroidvania type progression where you not only need keys to explore previous areas you also need certain powers. The fire power lets you see in the dark and if you combine your air and fire power you gain a defensive lightning shield which you need to navigate certain hazards.

>>9654896
Depends what you like. Most people consider WL4 the best one. It's WL2/WL3 but extremely streamlined in all the right ways with each level being more unique.

My favorite is WL3, due to it's massive sprawling Metroid-like progression abilities and level design of going to back to past areas to explore deeper parts of the level with new abilities which is pure dopamine for me. But it's a divisive entry BECAUSE of it's Metroid-design and Wario losing abilities he had in WL2, so you'll either think it's a masterpiece or hate it. Also the Golf minigame sucks.

WL2 is the foundation of which the future Wario Lands are based on. It's really cool due to it's alternate story routes. Though every chest having a mini-game roulette attached to it is so fucking annoying and I hate it more then the Golf mini-game of 3.

Both WL2/Wl3 Wario can't die, so much of the punishment is having your time wasted instead. Be prepared for that. Bosses are also puzzles that you have one chance to figure out, if you lose you have to restart completely.

Make sure to play Virtual Boy Wario Land as well. Very short but great to revisit the WL1 gameplay but more polished.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

My point is that the game forces you into a very narrow "problem-solving" approach both in map layout, units given and so on... certain units are specifically designated to defeat certain opponents and you almost always have to use them that way.

In "true" tactics games like XCOM or Tactics Ogre you are given a far more broad approach in dealing with situations tactically, rather than treating levels/battles as problems to solve a very specific way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646353
>why are there so many tactics ogre/fft clones but so little fire emblem clones?
I suspect it's for the same reason that there are so many Castlevania clones and so few Metroid clones. Namely, that the majority of people don't fully appreciate the subtle differences between the two and so anyone asking for Metroid-like games is pointed toward Castlevania-like games as if it's all the same. Similarly, anyone who asks for Fire Emblem-like games is simply pointed to FFT-like games instead.

I think it comes from one game just being more popular than the other so that's what gets copied most and then people who don't respect the nuanced differences between the two don't drive any demand for copies of the less popular one because they don't even see a need for it.

>>9656819
>Well that's a perspective I've never heard before and does make the idea of just skipping to FE3 a lot more appealing.
If you only want to touch any form of that game once, then yes skip to Book 1 of Mystery of the Emblem. I will say there is a magic to FE1 that no other FE games have that I feel warrants at least one playthrough, though the inventory system might be frustrating to deal with as it is admittedly clunky. But there's a magic to playing the games in order of release and seeing the evolution there. Otherwise you would have to play half of a SNES game, go back to play Fire Emblem Gaiden on the NES, then go back for the other half of the SNES game to play in order of "1, 2, 3" for the games.
The inventory system might of the original Shadow Dragon might be frustrating to deal with, though. Even when the game wasn't even a year old yet there was an interview with the series creator on Famitsu and he talked about how people complained about that inventory system. So in the SNES remake he listened to the criticism and he overhauled it to be more easy to use and far less clunky.

Brigandine is one of my favorite games and my main comfy fallback for when I need to retreat into my nostalgia dome and ignore the world for a weekend(rare that I get that much free time to myself anymore).
I learned to play the Japanese only(at the time, pretty sure there is a translation patch now) Grand Edition through trial and error then muscle memory.
Objectively it's probably only a 7/10, (the ai is stupid and once you learn how to play correctly, the game is never really difficult), but I still love the shit out of it. Even though the gameplay is different, at the time it was my successor to Dragon Force(where there are multiple factions to choose from with unique commanders and different stories for each). The Switch Brigandine game is fun, too, if you like the original. Not much it terms of changes, so it's just more of the same rather than changing or trying to revamp the system. I prefer the story and characters of the original probably just because of the nostalgia/familiarity but there's an obvious difference in the design with the new game having the giant anime tits that you'd expect out of any modern offering. >>9638864
I've not played all that much FE but that doesn't match my experience with them at all. Maybe on those really hard difficulty modes all the new games have now, but not on normal or hard in the older games.

They tend to have so many more playable units than there are deployment slots people just use their favourites and send everyone else to the bench, so it's not as if you're forced to use specific characters much.

And sure, you could argue those characters aren't always that different statistically, but you don't need to use especially specific class compositions either. You probably want a few staff-users and cavaliers, but when it comes to things like knights or archers, some people love them while others can't be bothered with them, and both get by just fine. You can take very different teams into the same map and come out on top. Not to mention sometimes a unit dies and you have to adapt to that. Sure you can reset, but not resetting or only resetting for really painful losses are definitely supported playstyles as well.

Regarding Advance Wars as well, maybe you only meant single-player, but AW has a big multiplayer community as well which doesn't seem plausible were it really a puzzle game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
FFVII has such a weird look for how much hype it got for its graphics—I don't mean it in a bad way though. It looks so distinctive, and very much a product of its time.
Most polygons are untextured and only have Gouraud shading. The chibi 3D models showed this weird transition from old FF to new FF. The whole style of the game is in this limbo of sorts between FFVI and full Nomura. There's already been enough said about the cutscenes and pre-rendered BGs, but today they got some vintage quality of that early 3D look like DKC, and I like small strange details in them like that My Bloody Valentine poster—areas from PS games like RE2 are full of mysterious references like these.
Overall, it looks imperfect, but that surprisingly gives it unique charm and soul, and makes it more interesting to look at than far more polished, generic-looking FFVIII (IMO).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9657639
>Filling in the blanks is what makes the picture interesting
Nah that's nonsense. I can dream up shit that's more interesting that FF7 while staring at a wall, but if it's all in my head what's the point. A world needs to be brought to life. The problem with modern graphics isn't that they're too detailed, it's that they introduced this "cinematic" mentality into the industry. Now every cutscene is a collection of close-ups, whereas before you saw the whole scene like you would in a theatre, and that placed you into the world better than a collection of flipping close-ups. Before nobody cared about how correct the sense of scale was, you could have a planet with 1 city and a dozen villages and nobody went WAIT A SECOND THAT'S NOT REALISTIC and it was fine. Now that dozen villages would be spread around a smaller hub area and you would never be allowed to explore the full planet because that's not realistic. It's a shift in mentality, and that shift sucks. Give me detailed graphics but remove all the cinematic nonsense that comes with it

The robots in megaman classic do have self-awareness and emotions, but what separates them from Reploids is the fact that they cannot act upon what they perceive and feel unless programmed to. Wily has to modify them into acting erratically and dangerously.
As for Rock in MM7, it could be that years of experience saving people and making choices, as well as continuous upgrades from Dr. Light eventually resulted in Rock developing a primitive form of agency that ALMOST emerged when he was about to shoot Wily (regardless of localization text because it sure looked like he was about to blast the old man's face right off). Light noticed this and thus began working on X. Is it canon? No, but it makes sense. Even our current-year primitive AI experiments eventually develops its own ideas that skirt the limits of what it's allowed to do, it's not far fetched.

Carbons are close to humans but not quite. They're a simulacrum, a "close enough" created to live on the planet until the last living true human died. Then the program would initialize to clone all the original humans and kill all the Carbons in the process.
In the eyes of the average person, Carbons are indistinguishable from people aside from the fact that they can swap out for robot parts really easily (which they don't question since they all can do it). In the eyes of the one last actual human in the world, they were not seen as humans until he actually observed their lives and realized they were living a more human life than he was as he had obtained functional immortality long ago, living in a paradise while the Carbons still dealt with age, disease, hunger, etc.

>>9654687
I agree with you. I’m always confused when people act like 3&K is the best of the genesis games. Its not a terrible game but I prefer 1, 2 or CD. Sonic 1 and 2 are great for reasons you mentioned. Linear, fast and fun almost arcade style games. Race through the level and beat the boss quickly, stopping only to get the chaos emeralds. Multiple paths but the best is always fast and gives lots of rings. Metropolis Zone in Sonic 2 feels like a preview of Sonic 3. Its long and gets old. The added content in 3 seems to just slow everything down. It felt like it was competing with something slower and more methodical like DKC of Yoshi Island rather than trying to be fast, arcadey sonic. All the different powerups and different kinds of bonus zones complicated things in the wrong way.

Of course levels like labyrinth Zone and Marble Garden Zone in Sonic 1 slow things down too. I love these levels. The difference is they are simpler in design and not as long and just don’t feel as padded out. Most levels in Sonic 3 wear out their welcome by the first zone in my opinion. Those slower levels in Sonic 1 remind me of 80’s platforming games. Alex Kidd, SMB, etc. The long ones in 3&K feel like Metropolis Zone times 3

Sonic CD is more about exploration and collection so the levels are more open. You can breeze through levels like in previous sonic games or you can try to find the collectables. Its a different game and I would say its a great twist. Rather tham just being longer and having more cinematic showpieces like 3, theres a real purpose and you’re actively looking for something.

I don’t mean to be too hard on 3&K. Saving makes up for my complaints and moves it from an arcade platformer and turns it into a longer experience like DKC, Super Metroid or Castlevanias. Instead of playing the whole game, the player is meant to play a level or two per sitting, keeping things fresh. It was an ok attempt at evolving Sonic and certainly better than 3d blast

>>9654962
Continuing my thoguht here:

Another defense of Sonic 3&K is that I really don’t know where else the series could have gone at that point. They couldn’t just keep making Sonic 2 level hacks forever. Sure Sonic Mania was great but should a new one have been released every year? Sonic CD was great too as a one-off experimental title, but it wasn’t the direction I would have taken the series. They went in one of the only directions they could have gone in by making longer levels, saving and more powerups and collectables. What else was there to do?

Maybe they could have eliminated levels and made it all one continuous (but still relatively linear) world like Castlevania 3. Branching level paths an so on.

Shortening down the levels to be like some of the real small ones in SMB3 wouldn’t have worked for Sonic. They added some gimmicks for 3 but making Sonic a new gimmick every level platformer like the excellent DKC2 would have desfroyed Sonic as well. Its just not Sonic. So given that I’m not sure where else they could have taken things, Sonic 3&K was a viable option.

>>9653791
Video game sequels had to be somewhat experimental back in the day in order to test the waters on want the general public wants from a video game sequel.
This is why Lost Levels wasn't localized and we got Mario 2 instead.
It's also why Zelda 2 is a radical departure from Zelda 1.
The thing about experiments is that they're not always successful.
Some people liked Castlevania II and appreciated the differences it brought to the table. Most didn't. This is why Castlevania III was a lot more like the first game, and the "metroidvania" concept was shelved for another ten years.

>>9658184
Even if the game WERE well-translated, it's extremely stupid to have a game where you can't tell whether the NPCs are lying to you or not. If there were some kind of magic lie detector item that told you when someone was lying, it would be different.
Take the stupid fucking Deborah Cliff hint, for example.
>>>9658242
>Hit Deborah Cliff with your head to make a hole.
By the time you've met the NPC who gives you this hint, the game has given you all kinds of bum information.
>A flame is on top of the 6th tree in Denis Woods.
>Rumor has it, the Ferryman at the Dead River loves garlic.
Therefore, the Deborah Cliff is gonna smell like bullshit from front to back.
It's okay that the game doesn't spell everything out for the player, and that "hit your head" is supposed to mean "crouch".
What's NOT fucking okay is that
1. There's no hint telling you how LONG you're supposed to crouch
2. There's no hint telling you that you need one of the crystals equipped here as well.
I'm not saying the game needs to spoonfeed us this information by directly telling us to wait a few seconds and to equip this specific item. I'm saying they should've incorporated these elements into the riddle in some way. "Hit your head on the cliff" is fine, but there's two other parts the game fails to tell you, and that's not good.
This is why it's a bad translation. The game simply doesn't give the player enough information to reasonably be able to proceed at this point in the game.

Fixed that for ya. The east is a nightmare of one-way roads, roundabouts, weird angles, curvy roads, and other stuff. Nearly everything west of the river of mud is a big grid and usually aligned to the compass. To travel to a store 4,000ft away from your home in California, you just head out to the next cross street, and head that way. To travel to a store 4,000ft away from your home in Florida, you head out to the next cross street, follow it 2,000ft in a completely different direction until it dumps you out onto another cross street, then go another 2,000ft closer to where you wanted to go, and then another turn and 3,000ft to your destination. And there's two canals full of gators and snakes preventing you from taking a direct route to bypass that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9659981
>hurr durr grids are for cars

Yeah, not quite. The Romans were well known for building their cities on grid patterns (Roman roads are also the only good European roads aside from the motorways, mostly because they're actually fucking straight and not some evolution of a goat path), Chinese cities were organized on grids (and Kyoto later emulated this), even Teotihuacan was on a grid. The grid pattern is just a sign of a highly organized civilization, and European cities just generally devolved into a jumbled mess after the orderly influence of the Romans was removed. When the Europeans finally regained some semblance of order and enlightenment, they built on grids (see: Lisbon after 1755, Lyon, Barcelona, Valencia, Stockholm).

Even a lot of American and Canadian cities have grids that predate the car. New York's grid system was planned in 1811. Toronto's grid was based off British concession roads that were laid out in the 1820s.

Now back to r/fuckcars with you

When civilization made a leap to rectangular buildings it did so because there was a need of mass manufacture of building elements and the ease of which buildings can be stacked next to each other.

Irregular building shapes meant custom building elements, custom furniture, custom everything.

And as soon as you have rectangular buildings it makes sense to do city planning in a grid.

It's just basic form follows function logic.

Good morning Sirs

Semi related, but the N64 will always be the golden era for multiplayer console games for me. We had the right age. By the time gamecube came around, it was getting harder to meet every week. And with the N64, three of us had the console, so we bought different games so we could exchange them with each other.

We had the most fun with 'Snowboard Kids'. Even more than 'Goldeneye'. Mariokart 4 player was lame, it didn't even have music in 4 player, so you had to listen to annoying buzzing sounds from the karts. Diddy Kong had the music on in 4 player, but it still wasn't very good. Snowboard Kids all the way.
Lylat Wars 4 player was barebones, but we had fun with it.
The king was the minigames on 'Pokemon Stadium'. I'd bought it and found the main game lame. But we used to play the minigames everytime, during our weekly meetup, getting drunk before we went out.
Quake II was a good one too, very underrated. And Micro Machines. Also spent a lot of time on 1080 snowboarding, not even on the twoplayer. We would time trial and then race each other's ghosts.

- Snowboard Kids
- Pokemon Stadium
- Goldeneye

Perfect Dark multiplayer was never that fun to us. Turok multiplayer was fun for 5 minutes. Smash Bros 64 looks like a game we could've had a ton of fun with. We just never knew about it, none of us three with a console had bothered to check it out.

Nintendo in general never quite popped off in Europe, unless you're counting the Fami-clones. N64 was semi-popular for a time because of Pokemon Stadium mostly, but yeah... That's on the company and their lackluster marketing though. The country with biggest Nintendo presence was Germany and even in Germany, you'd walk into a vidya store and Nintendo products would get a tiny-ass display rack, not an entire wall like with Sony or later on Microsoft products. Nintendo was always treated more as a Japanese and American cultural trend. Back in the day if you'd own a Gamecube, good luck swapping games with your buddies. Most of the kids at my school were into PS2 and Xbox, the Gamecube was seen more like a curiosity.

The Snes got a huge surge in popularity where I lived when they did a pricedrop and combined it with Super Mario All Stars. I only had one friend with a Mega-Drive. Nes and Master System where 50/50. I think Goldeneye moved more consoles than 'Ocarina of Time' even though 'Ocarine of Time' got on the news as 'The Videogame Of the Century'. Playstation was a bit like the Wii in the sense that it had very good marketing but most who got one weren't that interested in games. Xbox was a dudd. But it had some good games and was a quality console especially for a first try.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9659368
Part of the point with traditional fighters is it's not just a game of timing and strategy, but also player skill based on practice. Special and super moves are intentionally more difficult to do than basic punches and kicks to balance their usefulness and power. So say, doing Zangief's spinning pile driver. It's one thing to be able to do the move while practicing, but it's another to be able to do the move consistently at just the right time and under the pressure of fightingyour opponent. That is one of the displays of skill at the heart if these games and which makes sense because they're based on martial arts which are 99% practice in most cases.

So taking that aspect away or minimizing it the way smash does, has the effect of making it more accessible, but it also removes a level of skill. It's very much like in cart racing games where the player's ability to win is based more on the meta game of power ups and attacks rather than precise driving in a more sim based racer. So it's not bad, it's just different.

It would be like if you took basketball but gave players the ability where if they are within a certain range of the basket they can hit a button and have the ball automatically go in. It lowersthe barrier of entry for people who want to play basketball because they don't have to practice getting the ball in the net, just running around on the court. And while there is still a game there and skill to that aspect, in the end it's a very different experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653010
Anything you want to have shortcuts to on the system menu should run from the memory card, I think. In my experience trying to start apps from a system menu shortcut can make the system lock up if the HDD has to spin up first.

If you're concerned about memory card space you shouldn't really be using your FMCB card for game saves anyway. Best to just load up all your homebrew onto one card and use another one for saves (or a virtual card on the HDD)

Easy way to test this is to put in PS1 games or CDs and see if they work. If they work then the DVD laser is dead/dying and you need to replace it. You can try adjusting the potentiometer on the DVD laser but that's a band aid at best and might not work at all. Replacing the laser on the slim model is easy but you need a soldering iron to remove the anti static solder point. See pic related.

While it is a little known fact that a good half of the enemies in Dragon Warrior 2 hand out more exp/gold than their counterparts in Dragon Quest 2, what nobody knowns (and which isn't documented yet) is that the stats of all enemies were also rebalanced for the western version.

Every enemy in Dragon Warrior 2 is easier. Whether that is attack, def or agility, values, and I think in some cases even HP and probability to use this or that move (I'd have to check back to make sure of that). In most cases there are subtle changes to most values.

So when you see people who have played Dragon *Warrior* 2 and hear them cry about
>waaah this game is too hard! I mean the end game is hard how does that make sense??!! Look even the devs said it was too hard!
They have absolutely no right to use the dev stuff as an excuse because they were already playing a version in which the difficulty had been adressed to begin with.

Dilate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633787
While it is a technical possibility to get ambushed and OHKO'd from a death spell in the late game, it is very unlikely to happen when you reached the level gap. The higher your level, the less likely you will be to get ambushed, and the less likely death spells will be likely to hit.

>>9633749
>specially the sun one which is found on a specific tile on a southeastern shrine.

There is an NPC that tells you exactly where the shard is. That and you get the flute to help you locate the shards.That and the shrine is likely to be a place you visit when you use the warps.

As long as you pay attention and take notes when NPCs say things, you shouldn't have too much trouble.
Personally I love this stuff in the game, these adventure game mechanics are exactly what makes the game feel organic and alive, rather than having a game-y world with a tired "area is composed of one town, one dungeon, complete that and you're allowed to go the next area and repeat" routine.
In DQ2 towns work as hubs you come back to
in between several quests, and their inhabitants often provide clues that will be needed for things much later on; that and there is often a reason to come back to X or Y location later on. This makes the world feel alive and enhances the feel of adventure, something many other RPGs (DQ sequels included) fail at because they want to cater to the part of the audiance that just wanted to be hand holded through an adventure game.

>>9643348
The source is me checking the game code coupled with existing dissassembly and documentation to help (though I don't trust the dissassembly too much because external docs that come with it talk about things which aren't in the game at all, must be a romhack or something)

Example, Big Slug data in the Japanese version
08 00 03 01 04 0B 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

Big Slug data in the US version
08 00 03 02 03 09 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

So on top of the exp given being changed from 01 to 02 (already a known thing easily checked by playing or checking guides), the attack value was changed from 0B to 09, losing 2 points.

Pretty much every enemy has changes like that, some more substantial than that too.

I'll document it all one of these days, but it takes time; and I intend to check up on other things too like probability for enemies to use this or that spell or to drop items etc

>>9643352
>know more than the devs

The "we didn't have time to properly test and balance the game" excuse was from a Japanese interview, thus talking about the Japanese version. One should also take into account that they spent one month and a half (november/december 1986) doing nothing but debugging and balancing the game. That's a lot of time. The game was delayed for that purpose specifically.
The fact is, making RPGs hard and require grinding was a norm then, which as a whole gradually decreased with time (and the US version is from 1990, thus the adjustements)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646454
>he doesn't memorize an approximate amount of HP each enemy has to be as efficient as possible in combat
First off, enemies in DQ have a range of HP, something with 100 HP isn't always going to have that amount when you encounter it, you could encounter two of the same enemy but one will die earlier because it had 92 HP while the other had 103, the same is true for the amount of gold that enemies drop. This makes it especially difficult to try and not trigger a 25% range.
Secondly, I'm skeptical of the 25% HP thing even being true because from what I could find, one source says its 1/3 HP and another says its a remake addition and doesn't specify a threshold for "low" HP.
>Also you make it sound like one cast of Twhack/Sacrifice is going to wipe out your entire team every time
Did you not play DQ2 on NES? Sacrifice aka Kamikazee is a 100% guaranteed full party wipe, there is no chance of it failing, you just instantly lose. The same is true for when you have Cannock use it, although some enemies have the blessing of being immune to instant death.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just checked the code (again, US NES version) and whenever Gold Batboons attempts to do Sacrifice, it checks its remaining HP and compares it to value 1C, which equals 28 in decimal; and proceeds to fuck off if the value is higher.
28 being 25% of 112, the Gold Batboon's max HP value when it spawns (as stated HP may vary), so it's not really 25% of its health, but 25% of its max possible health.

One interesting thing I'm not sure I fully understand however is that if you have 2 Gold Batboons, it checks both enemies HP values. I *think* what happens is that Gold Batboon A may very well be the one to use Sacrifice if Gold Batboon B is the one with low HP; not that the player will know because he will be kill.

It doesn't take to know precise HP values nor to check a guide, just knowledge acquired from a previous fight. The semi randomized enemy HP values + attack values may sometimes lead to a miss by a few HP, but in my experience it's pretty rare (and it's how I realized that enemies had randomized HP values on my first playthrough)

Honestly it just seems like basic RPG playing to me before auto-targetting became a thing

Fun fact: the gold values are tied to the HP values, so if the enemy has -10% of its max HP value you'll get -10% of its max gold value

>>9653739
It's no different than books. You could have a library in your home, or you could read them digitally from your phone, PC, or a dedicated device like a Kindle. And yet if you talk to people who enjoy reading, most tend to prefer reading on physical paper books and dream of having a library in their home. Games are no different. A collection is just a library of games, and although you could play them on your PC, phone, or a dedicated device like a Mister, real hardware is always a better experience for various reasons. And the reality is that most readers tend to use a combo of ebooks and physical books, and may gamers do the same. I have a large collection, but I also own a Retroid that I play on in bed sometimes. I've also got flash cartridges, a few mini consoles (Egret and Astro City), and have some emulators set up on my PC. So it's not as if I don't know what emulation is like. I also strictly emulated before I was able to start building a collection.

I have some responses to some of your specific points but I'll out hem in a separate reply because this is getting long.

>You're literally paying hundreds to own a piece of plastic with a rom burnt on that takes up space in your house
The vast majority of retro games still cost less than new games - even heavy hitters like Donkey Kong Country and Super Mario World. A lot of the "expensive" ones cost around the same as a new game, like Super Metroid. Very few games actually cost hundreds of dollars. And while you could just argue that I'm out of touch since I'm in Japan, I use an app to track what I own and it pulls data from price charting. I have to input most of my collection as the US versions because their database doesn't have the Japanese versions, and I'm able to see that many of the best games for various consoles are still extremely affordable. Most games simply don't cost hundreds of dollars. Personally I've only spent "hundreds" on a single game, and all of the other expensive games I've bought were around a hundred.

And let's be honest: if you can't afford to buy games that cost less than new games, you're probably extremely poor. At that point you should just emulate or find a new hobby. But why attack other people who do collect just because you can't afford to do so?

>>9653739
I’ll answer honestly since your post seems genuine. There are a number of reasons for me.

1. First off, I don’t pay hundreds of dollars for anything emulatable. The only game I’ve ever spent over $100 on is a PS3 game that emulates like absolute shit. I might buy Steel Battalion someday. I VERY rarely spend more than $30 even. I just have a lot of old stuff and hunt for deals, which is part of the fun for me

2. I like to browse. Buying physical games from my local shop keeps them in business so I can browse. This is actually helped by the prices of sought-after games shooting up—since those are unavailable I look over the shelf for something affordable that seems interesting. It pushes me to explore the console’s library more and I’ve found some of my favorite games of all time this way.

3. While I don’t intentionally buy games as an investment, the value of my collection is at this point far beyond what I paid for it. If I managed to sell my collection off at going rate (unlikely without years of work, I know) I could pay the down payment on a house at this point

4. If I have a big rom list I just don’t play anything. Having physical games in my shelf encourages me to play through them, and browsing what I have can remind me to start or finish a game. It creates a contact point that just doesn’t exist for a rom list.

5. Maybe the most schizo point, but I don’t trust that piracy will remain as easy at it is now forever. Just because the internet has stayed relatively unregulated for this long doesn’t mean it will be that way forever. I could write a manifesto about this but won’t here and now.

6. They’re neato and old hardware is cool. Fixing consoles and such taught me soldering skills that I’ve used to make money as a side hustle. I like being the guy with shelves of old games. My friends think its cool I have certain rare games. My ex gf was impressed that I had a certain rare game.

I think that for a long time on the internet collectors were the main source of information and discussion for these older games. Most gaming publications were just talking about the newest games, but collectors would keep the discussion on retro games alive. Collectors who would dedicate entire YouTube channels to retro games put out reviews and got more people interested in them, which boosted the popularity of collecting. Of course some people saw money to be made in this growing collector's market and that's where Metal Jesus and companies like Limited Run came in, making game collecting a scummy practice. A core tenet of collecting was discovering the gems in the libraries of old game systems, but now those mines are mostly empty and the current retro market is grossly inflated.

I moved about 6 years ago and boxed up all my games and consoles. Friend of mine took the box and traded it in at a gamestop behind my back. Needless to say we're not friends after I found out.
So I lost every single game and console I had owned since I was a kid. I can't really get anyone around me to understand that I have a lot of memories attached to some of those games.
Like you're stuck at your grandparents on a summer day because your mom has to work. You come in late in the evening and you're playing megaman on your grandparents giant, old, woody, RCA tv... sitting in the floor- you and your grandmother take turns between lives; seeing who can get the furthest past quickman lasers and heatman disappearing blocks. The lights outside slowly start to fade making the TV's glow even more impressive. That desperate urge to beat just one more level before it's time to eat.
Maybe I'm stupid, but not having those old carts and cd jewel cases sitting on my shelf makes me feel like something is just missing.
Lately I've been trying to hunt down and buy back just some of the games I used to own as a kid.
I have been searching high and low for just a handful of titles and some of them are ridiculous. Like I'm quite attached to the megaman series... but $1-2k for Tron Bonne? That's a game I have distinct memories paying $40 from mowing lawns for at a bestbuy. I can afford it no problem, but I just can't make myself do it. It feels irresponsible.
There's emu, but damnit I just want those few good things that were attached to memories back.
Sorry about the blogpost.

Unfortunately I lost most of my childhood game collection through selling and trading, and I don't really have much left. It's really sad actually. After I moved overseas I started my collection by picking up various games that I enjoyed as a kid. That was basically my only goal in the beginning, but after a while I started branching out and picking up games I've never played and ultimately that's where most of my collection has come from and has led to the most enjoyment. It's nice to be able to pull out a game I liked as a kid, and it's nice to be able to open the closet or look over at the shelf and see a collection that I would have been so jealous of when I was younger. Like you said, a lot of great memories get attached to this stuff and playing and bring you back to another time. A while back I was replaying Super Mario Sunshine and it reminded me of staying with my grandparents over the summer while my parents went to some Jesus camp thing.

There are no compelling storylines or characters, though there were in some contemporary PC games.

The games people remember now—River Raid, Adventure, Yar’s Revenge—all have something visually unique, a good sense of progression or more modern gameplay mechanics. I wasn’t into games until after the NES’s heyday but it is easy to go back to them and enjoy what they have to present. Outside of historical curiosity, it is much more difficult to connect with an Atari 2600 game

Also, videogames are an escape from reality. Most adults that play them acknowledge this, and treat playing them as a mildly shameful weakness in their character, a coping mechanism for some insoluble problem. Collectors, on the other hand, refuse to acknowledge that games are an escape. By buying game objects for display, they indicate that they view the objects as worth showing off, either as an accomplishment of acquisition or devotion to the medium, or as art pieces with value inherent to themselves. As art objects they are tasteless and trite, but (more significantly) as marks of achievement, of exertion to acquire and master, they're fucking pitiful. The energy, money, and willpower spent searching for old game accessories could be spent hunting, fishing, woodcarving, traveling to foreign countries, playing musical instruments, sleeping with women, raising children, exercising; each of these things would yield their own trophies, far more valuable and worthy of display than children's toys acquired in adulthood. But coomlectors suffer from a sickness of spirit which precludes their participation in any really strenuous activities, so they regress to the acquisitive fantasies of their childhood and never manage to move on to trophies which suit an adult's capabilities
