posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Short version:
>play Pokémon red or blue on an OG Game Boy or a Super Game Boy.

Full Pocket Monsters experience: a /vr/ guide
>know absolutely nothing about the franchise and first engage with it through newspapers articles about a cartoon show that caused epileptic attacks on children in Japan
>read video game magazine articles that talk about a social phenomenon in Japan, called "Pocket Monsters", see some small screenshots and design imagen and think it looks weird and foreign but cool
>Call up various local game stores and ask them if they sell this japanese Pocket Monsters Game, only for them to have no idea
>forget about it for a while and one day you casually watch the first episode of "Pokémon" on cable TV and then you keep watching all the first season, meanwhile:
>Get Red or Blue and play on a Game Boy, or a Super Game Boy. Better alternative: GB tower on Pokémon Stadium, and using Oak's Lab for item and pkmn management, much better than the menues on the GB games. But, for a first playthrough it's not mandatory.
>Once you beat the game and catch Mewtwo, watch Mewtwo Strikes Back kino
>Read the "electric tale of Pikachu" manga
>Get a friend or a way to get the Pokémon from the other version that you're missing. Play Stadium's gym leader castle to get starters, fossils, eeveees and hitmons.
>Also try to beat the different cups in the main Stadium game as a post-game challenge. Start training low level Pokémon and buff them/give TMs and customize them.
>Buy at least a pack of the TCG, even if you don't care playing it, it's good art on them.
>play Pokémon Pinball and the Game Boy TCGs if you want somen extra gen 1 experience on GB
>play Snap and Smash 64
>Start reading rumours about pikablu
>Get hype for "Pokémon 2"
>Download a japanese ROM of Pokémon Gold and play a bit of it on a poorly coded emulator
>Play the actual Gold or Silver cart on a GB Color or go full pokemaster and play on Stadium 2 using the GB Tower, then play the Stadium cups.

Because cable got greedy and monopolistic as fuck. Most people nowadays loathe cable companies, they are the lowest of the low in company scores for years over. >>9658385
>Sony VS Bleem just set the precedent. Bleem wouldn't have won the case if the existing laws were not in their favor.

Not really how it works. Many things, especially new tech, operate in a grey area where it's not clear where the law stands on it. Many of these laws were made before the computer age, much less internet and digital mediums. The whole point is that lawyers argue which way the law is meant to be interpreted in these grey areas when it goes to court. It's also why many don't try to rock the boat too hard because they risk setting a precedent against themselves. Nintendo learned this the hard way when it managed to get videogame rentals go from a grey area to legal everywhere but the US. Nowadays they tend to strong-arm smaller groups but usually settle when it gets dicey if it's not a guarantee they can win rather than risk setting another precedent that is disfavorable towards their business.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The decision to design the system such that cartridges must be pressed down to play means that the pins make a very poor connection to the traces and will often fail to contact with them once they're bent from use and tarnished.

There used to be replacement 72 Pin connectors that were designed to NOT be pressed down and just made full contact with the carts immediately when they were inserted, and they worked fine, but it looks like those are completely out of production.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9654919
The NES was designed to not look too conventional as a game console, to more bring to mind a VCR, which was one of many aspects intended to ease over American retailers who weren't over Atari's Big Fuckup. Therefore, instead of a machine with a plain port on top, it has this mildly convoluted tilting carrier which you slide the cartridge into, then press down onto a springloaded catch.

This works, but it's also the kind of thing which is more delicate, it's very easy for a kid to put lateral leverage onto the connecting pins on the console and the cartridge by not being gentle enough, both when inserting and removing, and that kind of stress can add up to damage with time, leading to unreliable and inconsistent connection. It's just one of the facts with the NES, there's a reason the later 90s revision model of the NES, and the SNES and N64, were instead conventional toploaders with springloaded dustcovers, it's just cheaper and better.
I recall a few years back that someone had developed a retrofit kit for the NES, which replaced this whole tilting carrier setup with a rigid one where you only slide it in forward, but I don't think they've been produced for a while.

If you have an NES which seems to have damaged pins, or a cartridge which does (both can be damaged), then you can usually fix the problems by very carefully tweaking the pins to get them back into shape.
Optionally, you can replace the entire connector pin set, and replacement sets are still available for sale online in 2023, they're not that expensive, but quality can also vary a lot, many are pretty chintzy. Mind, sometimes the pins could simply be dirty, who knows who did what to the console or cartridge when you buy one used, and dirt from a dirty cartridge can rub off into the console's own connector pins, so try cleaning the pins carefully with Q-Tips and isopropyl alcohol first.

The PCB is also bigger and has more spacing between components than the Famicom. This may have been done with the idea of improving the thermal environment since the early Famicoms had issues with hot PPUs and actually had a heat spreader on them. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9654919
ZIF (zero insertion force) socket.
It was designed to be easier to insert cartridges and less damaging from friction, but the metal contacts get pushed in after a certain point and start to lose contact. The lockout chip wouldn't even be a problem if the connection was good enough, so it's more the ZIF socket's fault.
Fortunately it's completely possible to fix an original ZIF socket by bending the pins back into place without having to replace it with some cheap Chinese knockoff that damages your carts. Look up a tutorial, it's easy.

>>9653470
This whole conversation around the Saturn being a magical 2D powerhouse always comes off as a hypercorrection of its failure. Not saying that it doesn't have the edge in 2D over the PS1, but that the Saturns ability for 2D shines best when you don't notice it. It has a really faithful arcade ports and as a consequence you're never really thinking about what the console is doing, especially nowadays where we can play most Capcom/SNK stuff wherever we want. That said, I think stuff like Princess Crown and Dragon Force strike me as being impossible to run on the PS1 without some heavy compromises.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9658308
Thats kinda why i made this thread. I had a Saturn in the 90s i bought off a friend of a friend with a bunch of games and at the time, i only found it ok. I didn't think to delve deeper into the library at the time or the imports until years later and only recently acquired some more interesting games such as Leynos 2, super tempo and op image.

All these years online i heard people saying Saturn was a "2D powerhouse" and i guess i never saw what they were referring too, like was it the rpgs/visual novel art? The shmups? Is it literally all just focused on the arcade ports? I guess i wanted to find stuff that pushed 2D game design past the 16bit era and showing what the hardware could do for console original games had things not jumped to 3D focused. I realize like above post says, psychic assassin uses a lot of 3D elements, but its in the service of a 2D focused game, plus other hardware gimmicks. I think it was the first 2D style game i played where i went "huh thats neat" in regards to stuff it does compared to the era its from.

Princess Crown is another i always thought looked interesting so i definitely want to try that out sometime.

>>9658753
>Snatcher silvers in the 90s or what?
Snatcher wasn't going for thousands of dollars in 1994-1995. the game was released in a few western regions with a small print run (according to interviews with Jeremy Blaustein) and was hyped by a few magazines. I remember buying a copy used for like $20 back in the day. The value of Snatcher only went up after the popularity of games like Metal Gear Solid 2 and such. Back in the early 90's I would ebay for Snatcher and find copies going for $20.00. But in the 2000's that game was going for hundreds (depending on the quality) I owned multiple Sega CD units in the past. I had a Cd burner in 2000 and I was making Sega CD .iso's with NERO and Alcohol 120%. back between 1992 to 1996, CD burners were available but were also expensive. But maybe for larger scale piraters, it could have been worth the investment? But for individuals, not really.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9655790
Can you upload it here?
If you want to port the official english script to the spanish translated rom of the SNES game it's doable
>use relative search tool (monkeymoore)
>tbl acquired
>open rom hex editor with tbl file
>text location acquired

Spanish sentences are longer than English and has all English letters so yes you could get away with a hex edit job directly in the hex editor, but in case you want to insert longer scripts you'll have to understand the game's pointers (also updated by the spanish translation patch so also possible to edit and accomodate a longer english script)

Reason why nobody did it yet: SaGa games in their original incarnations were rushed incomplete to the market, the updates bothered to restore the unused content since the original director is still at Square and still gives a damn about the franchise. Unlike Final Fantasy lazy cashgrabs, they're the actual definitive editions.

Now if you want to translate the K-Edition for Dragon Quest III, we're talking. Even the original patch for DQ3 is buggy, glitchy and incomplete
